Author: gyro_robo
Content: UPvoted for title!  Reminds me of the Animal House fraternity.

Author: ujeezy
Content:
I'm about to move out to Silicon Valley, and I need a place to live. I would really like to room in a house or apartment with a bunch of other hackers and/or entrepreneurial types.

Is anyone else is in a similar position? Or does anyone know of someone looking for a roommate or to sublet?

I am now regretting the fratty "Hacker House" parenthetical in the title, but I think it'd be fun as hell to bring a bunch of hackers together into a nurturing environment, where we sip not from foamy Dixie cups, but from the fountain of our collective knowledge.

If there're a lot of us, I'll throw together a hacker housing app to help everyone get in touch.

Author: donna
Content: My question is: Can we build a mind out of software that aggregates millions of minds?

Author: mynameishere
Content:
I don't have anything against java applets, but I'd like to hear their rationale for using them--pg is known to have publicly criticized java, after all.

Applets only have one major problem, which is their iffy deployment process. Once running, they're about as good as a desktop application.

Author: gyro_robo
Content:
There's a difference between critiquing ideas and ad hominem attacks.

"Think smarter" is so vague and nebulous it can refer to anything you want it to. This is the first time I've heard it refer to "focus", as that usually falls under the category of... "focus". And certainly it's the first time I've read advice to "think more thoughts" claim to mean "focus on one thing", and "think faster" claim to mean "spend more time on something".\n

Author: elq
Content:
An interesting essay on competition - http://software.ericsink.com/Choose_Your_Competition.html

All of Eric Sink's essays are valuable to a founder, at least as food for thought.

Title: Niklas Zennstrom on Entrepreneurship & Scratching Your Own Itch (and not having a business plan)

Author: palish
Content: Focusing on one thing at a time falls under "think smarter".  Do you not get anything done because you're scatterbrained or something?  Yeesh, I've elicited an almost religious response from you.

Author: gyro_robo
Content:
> There's still a higher probability that you WILL come to your desired solution if you have more thoughts.

Sounds like an unsupported assertion to me. And not how the brain seems to work, at least that we can tell -- e.g. computer chess vs. human chess. You seem to be describing a brute force approach.

> The trick is to focus on one thing at a time.

That sounds awfully contradictory.

> Your reply really gets under my skin for some reason.

Tripe like "think smarter" gets under mine. This ain't no pointy-hair seminar!\n

Author: gyro_robo
Content:
Except you don't get points for merely getting on base -- it's not "success". And if the bases are loaded, a safe double is better than a home run with bases empty.

As for Sequoia, they funded YouTube. If they had thought it could go public, why would they sell to Google? I assume because getting bought by an established company with a very strong stock status is preferable to rolling the dice -- IPOs can go straight downhill.

I think it's pretty obvious that they never planned on an IPO, but instead on a bidding war between Google, Yahoo, and Microsoft (and maybe others).\n
